awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Understanding Urban Vibrancy: A Geographical Learning Approach Employing Big Crowd-Sourced Geo-Tagged Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Vibrant communities are defined as places with the following features: permeability, vitality, variety, accessibility, identity, and legibility. Developing vibrant communities can help boost commercial activities, enhance public security, foster social interaction and, thus, yield livable, sustainable, and viable environments. With the advent of the mobile and sensing technologies, big crowd-sourced geo-tagged data (BCGD) are increasingly available from diverse sources (e.g., buildings, vehicles, human, sensors, devices) in urban space, and represent an invaluable source of intelligence for understanding urban vibrancy and enhancing smart growth. This project will develop novel, systematical, and effective analytical techniques to significantly advance critical problems in urban vibrancy by taking advantage of the wealth of BCGD. The algorithms and tools developed in this project will directly impact community planning,  city governance, and urban economics. The educational component of this project includes developing a new curriculum that incorporates research into the classroom and provides students from under-represented groups with opportunities to participate in research.


This project will develop new analytical techniques to discover, analyze, and leverage the patterns within and the relationships among BCGD to understand and sustain urban vibrancy. Novel methodologies that are appropriate to urban vibrancy will be designed in three directions: measurements, patterns, and mechanism. In researching measurements, axioms that a metric of urban vibrancy should satisfy will be introduced, and principled metrics will be devised to evaluate community vibrancy and learn how it is distributed. In researching patterns, an analytic framework will be proposed to discover the complex patterns of spatial configuration from BCGD for urban vibrancy. This framework aims to identify the compatible dimensions and corresponding measuring methods, as well as optimal portfolios and geographic presentation of spatial configuration. In researching mechanism, new machine learning models will be developed to examine the impact of spatial configuration on urban vibrancy by exploiting the conformity between spatial view and mobility view and the regularity of geographic dependencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed novel, systematical, and effective methods to address the measurement, patterns, and mechanism challenges in understanding urban vibrancy using crowd-sourced geo-tagged data. In researching measurements, we found that the unmeasurable urban vibrancy can be measured by geographic, human mobility, socioeconomic data from mobile Apps and mobile devices.  We have proposed a socioeconomic metric to evaluate urban vibrancy and used the metric to discover how urban vibrancy varies within and between communities in Orlando during the covid19 period, which is particularly meaningful for city situational awareness under the context of pandemic and economic reopen. In researching patterns, we have generalized a new topic of spatial representation learning and developed novel and systematical algorithms to overcome collective, dynamic, substructure, and interactive challenges in representation learning. In researching mechanism, we have proposed new machine learning approaches to exploit the regularity of geographic dependencies and the representations of urban forms to model urban vibrancy. In addition, we have extended the urban vibrancy concept and developed an adversarial generative modeling based automated urban planning system to reimagine the future of city configurations. The geoAI research results have received SIGKDD 2018 Best Student Paper Finalist and the SIGSpatial 2020 Best Paper Runner-up Award. The results have been used in various data science courses (CS5420, CS6001, CS3001 at Missouri S&T, CAP5610 at UCF) for both undergraduate and graduate students. For instance, the deep representation learning, deep spatial and sequential learning has been integrated as course materials. The results have been published timely in international conferences and journals (AAAI, SIGSpatial, SIGKDD, ICDM, ACM TKDE, ACM TSAS, Frontier in Big Data, etc.) and be distributed world-wide for education and research. The results have impacted on civil engineering, regional planning, and public health research.  The NSF REU supplement support has involved UCF undergraduate students into research. Two doctoral students partially supported by this project have graduated and joined academia as tenure-track professors.


Last Modified: 05/01/2022
Modified by: Yanjie Fu
